comment.author: 7687126@N06
comment._content: The Lady Jocelyn was built in 1852 for the General Screw Steamship Company. When the company collapsed she was renamed Brazil. She was then taken over by Shaw, Savill, Albion & Co. and used on the New Zealand trade as a sailing ship under her original name.

comment.author: 11946814@N02
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called AQUELLOS MAGNÍFICOS NAVIOS, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 38535102@N04
comment._content: is it not a shame... that ships only have a shelf life.l served on a number of ships all of which because l worked on them and that you have a sense of pride because as a sailor your ship gave you shelter and food.The sea was often unpredictable and because of that you always did as you were told All hands on deck Some people have no idea about being a sailor.Which leads me to this ship. lt can tell some tales and l bet the former sailors with bare foot up the mast were the bravest of the brave.

comment.author: 44176794@N02
comment._content: Me encanta .....me inspira y las palabras no para de dar vueltas en mi cabeza, pidiendo a gritos salir, para crear una novela...........

comment.author: 48019362@N04
comment._content:
My great-grandmother sailed to NZ on the 'Lady Jocelyn', departing Gravesend 28 Sept 1880 and arriving Lyttleton (via Tauranga and Aucklans) 24 Feb 1881.
If anyone can direct me to a site where I can get more information and pictures re that trip I would be eternally greatful.

comment.author: 49132326@N03
comment._content: re kiwicolleen. visit www.cossar.co.nz for a voyage diary, and passenger list. My grandfather ws on-board, also. Cheers.
